content.rendered:
This Dreamforce was c-razy!!  Not only was it my first Dreamforce as an MVP, but it was also the Dreamforce of back to back action.  Here’s a bit about my #DF18 adventure…

Getting to #DF18

This year Dreamforce was Tuesday September 25th – Friday September 28th in San Francisco, CA. I like to fly in the day before to get situated before the rush, so I arrived Monday September 24th, but it seemed like I was already late to the party.  I was staying at the Mayflower Hotel, about a 15 minute walk from the Moscone Center, not too bad, so after fighting rush hour (well after my awesome Lyft driver fighting rush hour from SFO) I dropped my bags and connected with some Ohana. The night was an early one with traveling but we grabbed a late dinner and said some hellos making plans for Tuesday.

The Start of Dreamforce

Tuesday I was able to start practicing first thing in the AM for my presentations.  DF18 I had 1 session submitted, but 3 sessions I was presenting, all of which were on Thursday.  Thursday was going to be crazy.  Tuesday afternoon I was ready to get out and about so I met up with  Medhanie Habte, then we later met up with  Jarrett Taylor, two amazing members of the Ohana, we spent our day with together.

That night was my very first MVP party where I met up with none other than my  System Dot Debug co-host  Bryan James, who is also a new MVP, Stewart Edeal, Lauren Touyet, and more! It was a blast! After the party it was back to the hotel, only 2 more sleeps until the big presentation day!! Wednesday was a quiet day. I met up with friends for brunch after another morning of reviewing my decks and then spent the day catching up with Ohana around the city. Back to my room to review my decks and early to bed, Thursday was going to be a BIG day.

Presentation Day

The next day was the day, Thursday, the day of sessions. I keep talking about these sessions. You’re probably wondering, what are they?  Well, they were pretty darn sweet.  First up was the 9 am session. We needed to be in the speaker room at Moscone West at 830 AM so rush rush rush that morning. I was up early and had to be ready to go for the entire day when I left the room.  So 830 I’m in the speaker room ready for that session numero uno.

This session is the session I submitted with Leslie Gestautas and Jean Velonis: Decoding Developers: Step Up Your Admin Career with Tips from an Admin, Developer and Architect.  This was a repeat of our session last year.  Sadly, prior to Dreamforce one of the 3 Amigas, Leslie, determined she would be unable to attend, leaving us one amiga short. Devastated, Jean and I debated whether or not we should throw in the towel, we decided to see if we could find a replacement, and Ashley Allen was able to step in as the Admin.

Decoding Developers

Our presentation starts with each of our journeys, how we got to where we are today.  Then we each tell 2 stories from our Salesforce lives that taught us valuable lessons in the world of  administration/development and/or how admins work with devs.

My first story was one of the favorites from last year, a first hand account of how you need to watch your language and use your eyes.  I talked about being in the room with the client and how we had a roadblock, and when a solution came to my mind. Rather than state we had an option and that we could move on, I got excited. I started talking too fast, blurted out an overly technical answer with far too many details, and by the time I looked around the room I realized I had lost everyone.  It was an “oh what did I just do moment“, it didn’t go over well. Making sure you are talking on the level of your audience, you are staying and the right depth of answers for the meeting you are in. Using the terminology your client uses, all these things matter.

To find out about Jean’s stories, Ashley’s and my awesome tips on having declarative coding standards, you can check out my first presentation of the day’s materials here:  Decoding Developers: Level Up Your Admin Career. 

DemoJam: Custom Themes for  Communities

 Next up I had a short break before my 1 pm session, which was a  Demo Jam: Custom Themes Community Cloud at the Palace Hotel. Now this session was pretty sweet. The hosts were David Green, VP Rockstar Salesforce and Thomas Krawczyk, PM Product Marketing Salesforce, and the session had both Nathan “Paprika” Pepper and myself competing against each other with custom themes we created for lightning communities. A few weeks before Dreamforce Nathan and I were asked if we wanted to be part of a Demo Jam for communities, we couldn’t have been more excited.

Although we were battling each other in the contest, Nathan and I are friends and often collaborate on our weekend ideas for fun projects. We build and helped each other out to bounce ideas during the build process.   Having the ability to build custom themes, such a new part of Salesforce, and now in  Winter 19 available to export from the Community Builder. The contest was a great success with Nate showing off his brewery theme AKA the Paprika Theme and me showing off my blog conversion theme AKA the Brodvalue Theme. you can find all the Resources on the page here:  Demo Jam: Custom Theme Community Cloud.

Deliver Personalized Content with CMS & Audience Targeting on Community Cloud

Last up was the big one, the presentation with 3 Salesforce rockstars.  I was so nervous. After finishing the Demo Jam it was time to run (literally) back to Moscone West for my 230 presentation. I was expected to meet my crew (co-presenters and handler) 30 minutes before the session in the speaker room.  My 1 pm Demo Jam was supposed to go until 1:30, but with questions and such after 1:30 quickly became 1:50. So off to the races, and barely made it.  At 2:15 I landed in the session room itself, where everyone was on stage waiting for me.  I greeted my handler,  Andy Schmiechen, it was so nice to see him again.  Andy and I goway back, we’re Ohana from the Twittersphere, he invited me to present at the WI User Group back in 2017, we’ve hung out at events, and he’s a member of  Ohana Slack.

Meet the team

In addition to seeing Andy, I was able to finally meet my co-presenters that I’ve been practicing with on the phone.  First, there was Neil Hayek; Neil is the Product Management Director of Files for Salesforce.  Dude is an expert at files, documents and content, and he emceed our presentation.  Then there was Shubhi Goyal, Senior Software Engineering at Salesforce.  She focuses on the CMS product.  After Shubhi there was Rohan Pande, Software Engineering Manager, Salesforce, who specializes in the Audience Targeting Functionality and its creation and enhancement.

Our presentation covered a number of topics during the hour we had, so in the prior weeks we had to practice, practice, practice to keep everything covered, but within the time block without us speed talking. First up Neil did our introductions, telling everyone who we are and what we do. Each of us that presented functionality, Shubhi, Rohan, and myself. 

Following introductions, Shubhi was up.  She started us off speaking about the brand  new Native CMS that’s now available in Communities, showing Collections, Native CMS, the new CMS Content object, and the different views within the Community. Then I spoke about CMS Connect with a WordPress to Salesforce demo – plus the Community view. Following my demo, Rohan did his demo of audience targeting, showing how different content can be displayed for different users.  In addition he showed the the new Winter 19 functionality that allows for both  AND and OR functionality with the criteria for dynamic components.  You can checkout the complete video and the session deck and details here:  Deliver Personalized Content with CMS & Audience Targeting on Community Cloud.

End of Day

That was it, my day of presentations was finally over, but Dreamforce certainly was not! I could take a break for the evening to rest, but the next morning I had another big event, the Community Cloud + Salesforce.org Farewell breakfast.  This breakfast was the opportunity for the Community Cloud to give back to non-profits and work together with Salesforce.org.  Thomas Krawczyk had invited me to be on of the Community Cloud experts at this event, where I would be able to use myCommunity Cloud knowledge to help out existing and new non-profits.

Farewell Coffee

The event started with breakfast and coffee at 9 am going til Noon. After a bit of networking a presentation started, showing off some of the basics of the community cloud, from how to build a page to the different themes.  After the demo, Q&A started. The first hands were raised, and answered by the presenter, and then the lines started.

It was announced that the people wearing yellow visors are community cloud experts and that the attendees should not hesitate to ask their questions to those of us wearing them.  It started with a few one off easy questions. Can I do this, which type of license is need for this, do communities do this? As I answered more and more questions, the line of people waiting to have me answer questions kept growing.  I sat down to chat with the presenter, ask about a future item and we got to talking.  My jam for 3 years has been Communities, so users directed to me too.

I have to say, I felt so honored that Thomas and the Community Cloud team kept directing people to me for customers and partners to have their questions answered.  The Community cloud is my passion, as is helping people. It was amazing to be able to help out so many people and to be able to keep helping a few of them on an ongoing basis by having them join Ohana Slack and stay in touch via email and Twitter. Not to mention, they had great swag, with books, Community Cloud nail files, body cream, pins, stickers, collapsable Community Cloud mugs, and those sweet sweet Community Cloud visors available. I still love wearing my visor out and about.

Recap

Overall it was an amazing Dreamforce 18.  I had an amazing time with Ohana, be them partners, customers, or Salesforce themselves, new friends and old.  I loved presenting each one of my sessions, they were amazing!  It seems that others enjoyed my presentations as well, so it seems to be a win across the board.  Like all good things, Dreamforce 18 had to come to an ended. Eventually there had to be goodbyes and we all made plans to meet up again throughout the year. I’m looking forward to an exciting 2019 and the new Ohana and learning it holds.

Hopefully I will have the opportunity to present again!  Those of you considering presenting, I recommend starting with a Community event. Community events are smaller, more laid back, you can interact more with the audience during and after. From there work your way up to Dreamforce, and I’ll see you on stage for #DF19 too!  Until then, I’ll see you around the Ohana!

jetpack-related-posts.title: DF19 OhanaSlack Ice Cream Social
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Dreamforce 19 was amazing, wasn't it? So much fun seeing so many Ohana, all the awesome sessions, cool announcements, Obama!!! But this year at Dreamforce, I was able to do something a little extra special, and decided to try to bring some Ohana together myself. Knew before that planning things for…

jetpack-related-posts.title: Salesforce Events 2020
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: The Salesforce Events 2020 is live!! That's right Ohana, it wouldn't be my blog if I wasn't talking about events and how we connect and get together as humans.  For real, we get out from behind the keyboard, and even leave the HOUSE!!! I know, it's crazy, but for Ohana,…

jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: My experience at Connections 18 and updates to CMS Connect for your Lightning Community, learn all about it here!

jetpack-related-posts.title: Jumping on the Clean up Bandwagon
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: "Clean up, clean up, every Admin everywhere clean up, clean up every Admin do your share..." OK, enough chanting of songs by purple dinosaurs.  So everyone is talking about cleaning the org for a fresh start to 2015, but I don't feel like we are really digging into the horrible…
